title: Relevance Feedback Content-Based Image Rertieval with Hierarchical Gaussian Process Bandits

author: Ksenia Konyushkova, Department of Computer Science, University of Helsinki

segmentation: Hello, my name is Sonia and I'm going to present you the work that is done at the University of Helsinki and Helsinki Institute of Information Technology and this work is done with the supervision of Donald Malaska and so are we consider problem of image retrieval in the database of unannotated pictures.
That means that we don't have any keywords associated with pictures or any natural language text and when the user is.
Unable to query the system by context, we employ the relevance feedback mechanism to navigate in the image space.

For instance, consider an example of a journalist looking for a picture to illustrate his article about maternity and the idea of such an image may be quite weak, and in order to navigate there he may use the relevance feedback to indicate what pictures are closer to his ideal target in order to move on and so.

Next, slide and in the next slide the data flow in the system is presented and we employed to level Gaussian process bandits in order to tackle this problem, and this is a kind of exploration exploitation algorithm.
That means that we want to.
The one hand we want to exploit the knowledge that we got in this system.
We want to explore that limited relevance feedback that we got, but on the other hand we want to reduce the uncertainty in this system and.

Explore other opportunities and usually this algorithms are designed to sample only one object per iteration and the system operates through a sequence of rounds where set of K images is presented and the problem of choosing K images is a little bit tricky, and especially when we consider a case of hierarchical bandits and we use Gaussian process beliefs to use it as a fake feedback in the system to ensure that.
The set of images is diverse enough.
And in order to be applied in the real life system, this type of algorithms for image retrieval should be time efficient and easily scalable for large sizes of the database.

Studies with rarely uses to indicate whether they can make use of the system, and we consider a set of tasks for them.

So thank you for your attention.
